State of Michigan
DEPARTMENT OF
HEALTH AND HUMAN
SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD
WELFARE LICENSING
RICK SNYDER NICK LYON
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 21, 2018
Thomas Scheuer
Oakland County DHHS
51111 S Woodward Ave
Pontiac, MI 48342
RE: License #: CP630201334
Oakland County DHHS
51111 S Woodward Ave
Pontiac, MI 48342
Dear Mr. Scheuer:
Attached is the Renewal Report for the above referenced facility completed on November
12-November 20, 2018. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of
the contract and ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Venus M. Decker, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(248) 639-9585
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP630201334
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768

Pontiac, MI 48342

Original Issuance Date: 06/01/1993
Service Types:

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training
(2) The foster parent training plan shall provide for all of the
following:
(c) Not less than 6 hours of training annually for each
licensee after the time periods specified in subdivision (b)
of this subrule.
Six foster parent files were reviewed. One out of six did not
have 6 hours of training annually documented. From the report
period 9/13/17-9/13/18, there was only two hours documented.
R 400.12325 License recommendation
(1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts
contained in the foster home evaluation and any
special evaluations.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall
recommend to the department the issuance of a
regular license or the continuation of an active
license only when all rules are in compliance or both
of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been
developed. The plan shall be in compliance with all of
the following requirements:
Three special evaluations were reviewed. One out of three did
not have the appropriate licensing actions. The home is
concurrently licensed as an AFC and Foster care home. The
home is in violation of ACT 116 722.111a and Foster Home
Rule 400.9401. The agency did receive permission from central
office to continue the license until the adoption was finalized but
no CAP was created documenting either violation.
4

R 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to
accept the foster child.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed
by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
Three borrowed homes were reviewed.
Three out of three homes did not have documentation that the
foster parent is willing to accept the foster child prior to
placement.
Three out of three homes did not have documentation that the
foster parent has received orientation to the policies prior to
placement.
Three out of three homes did not have a copy of the foster
parent/agency agreement signed by the foster parent prior to
placement.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(4)Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
Three special evaluations were reviewed. One out of three did
have a written report within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation. The conclusion o the investigation was on 7/24/18
and the report was written on 8/16/18.
5

R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in
R 400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(g) Documentation of the child’s placement preparation.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of eight did not
have documentation of the child’s preparation before placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did
not have documentation that information was shared with the
new placement consistent with R 400.12417.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did
not have a physical examination completed every 14 months.
The initial physical exam was completed on 6/29/17. An
updated one is not completed at this time.
6

R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did
not have document the above information was provided to the
foster parent before placement. The child was placed on 5/9/18
and the DHHS-3307 was completed on 5/14/18.
REPEAT VIOLATON-INTERIM 2017
7

R 400.12420 Updated service plans
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information: (c) A summary of information pertinent
to the updated services plan received since the last
service plan from the child, the child’s parents or
legal guardian, foster parents, referring agency, and
others, unless the agency documents why any of
these entities cannot be involved.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Ten updated service
plans were reviewed. One out of ten did not have a summary
of the pertinent information received since the last placement
from the caregiver. The caregiver (CCI) information was “cut
and paste” from the ISP.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
R 400.12420 Updated service plan
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(d) Assessment of progress in achieving the permanency
goal for the child.
Ten updated service plans were reviewed. Two out of ten
service plans did not have an assessment or progress in the
achieving permanency goal for the child. One of the service
plans was missing this information and the other was “cut and
paste” from the ISP.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
R 400.12420 Updated service plan
8

(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(e) A plan which includes any changes made since the
previous plan and which has the content specified in R
400.12419.
Ten updated service plans were reviewed. Four out of ten
service plans did not have a plan which included changes made
since the previous plan. Parent agency treatment plans did not
include an update of the goals or action steps and in some
cases did not reflect the information provided in the service
plan.
9

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational
statewide automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which
will be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
The following documents were missing in MiSACWIS:
 Renewal verification forms
 Closing BCAL-259
 Renewal letters
 Medical passport
10

REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
ISEP 6.18 Page 23 Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness
(Commitment 54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative foster parents
within 180 days of the date of placement.
There were 21 enrollments. Nine-teen enrollments were relatives. Sixteen of them
were over 180-day mark to license the home.
ISEP 6.17 Page 23 Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Generally (Commitment
53).
(a) Relative caregivers will be licensed unless exceptional circumstances
exist such that it is in the child’s best interest to be placed with the relative
despite the relative’s desire to forgo licensing. Such circumstances must be
documented in the child’s case file and approved by the County Director or,
in a Designated
County, a county-level child welfare Administrator.
(1) In such circumstances:
(i) the relative caregiver and the other adult household members must meet
the same safety standards as non-relative providers;
(ii) the relative caregiver must be fully informed of the benefits, including the
exact amount of monetary benefits, of licensure; and
(iii) the relative caregiver must sign a waiver stating understanding that he
or she is foregoing the benefits, including the exact amount of monetary
benefits of licensure.
Eleven foster children are placed in unlicensed relative homes. A waiver has not
been signed, nor an application for licensure. The earliest placement dating back
to 2/23/17. The most recent dated 8/9/18.
ISEP 6.49 – Page 34 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care provider shall
receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must contain the information
required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or
any successor policies approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly
thereafter, an
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the “Medical
Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any
successor policy approved by the Monitors), and provided to the foster care
provider.
Four out of eight foster care files did not have the initial medical passport signed
by the caregiver or an updated medical passport completed quarterly.
11

ISEP 6.33(c) Page 28 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment
69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the caseworker’s
supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of age to participate. If the
parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not available or decline to sign the plan,
the service plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to involve
them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Three out of eight foster care files did not have signatures from the parents.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722.03 page 14-16 Placement exception request (PER) –
Was a PER completed when required and completed quarterly.
A placement must not be made if it will result in one of the following:
Three out of eight foster care files did not have the PER’s completed when
required, specifically for sibling splits. Two files did not have the quarterly PERS
completed and one did not have the initial PER completed at initial placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
FOM 722-03 Page 18 Placement Change
Two out of eight foster care files did not have the required DHS-69 in the file for a
placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
12

DHHS Policy FOM 801 – Page 17-18 - - At the time of the first placement, the
care provider shall be given the Medicaid Number and a Medical Treatment
Authorization Card upon placement. Routine, Non-Surgical Medical Care
Two out of eight foster care files did not have the DHHS-3762 in the file.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Page 2 Required Participation in Development -
Foster Parent / Caregiver
Two out of eight foster care files did not have the caregiver signature on the
PATP.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
DHHS Policy 722-09 – page 9-15 - USP must include an update of: school
progress, emotional and physical development, child’s behavior, child’s
activities, significant events since last report, placement information,
placement resources, current placement, residential care, and permanent
wardship.
Three out of eight foster care files did not have an USP with the above updates.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 4 –Barriers affecting parenting time: Did the
agency identify and address factors that might affect the quality or
frequency of parenting time?
One out of three foster care files did not have the barriers affecting parenting
time documented. This part of the service plan did not have any information in it.
DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 3-4 – Parenting time Supervision: Did the
caseworker personally observe parenting time at least once a month
Three out of eight foster care files did not have the caseworker observe parenting
time monthly.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 4-5 – Initial Parenting time: Did the initial
parenting time visit should occur within two business days, but no later
than seven business days following placement.
One out of eight foster care files did not have an initial parenting time visit
documented within 7 business days following placement.
13

DHHS Policy 722-06I – page 4-5 –Parenting time age of child: The
frequency of parenting time is based on the age of the youngest sibling.
Newborn to age five, visits occur, at a minimum, two times per week.
One out of eight foster care files did have parenting time documented twice a
week as outlined above. Parenting time was only occurring once a week until
June 2018, when placement was in April 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
DHHS Policy FOM 722 – 03C – pages 1-2 – documentation: preparation for
independent living is required for all youth in foster care - age 14 and older
One out of eight foster care files did not document preparation for independent
living.
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06I - Page 11-12 – SIBLING VISITATION AND
ONGOING INTERACTION: Siblings not placed together shall have at least
one visit per month unless the visit may be harmful to one or more of the
siblings, the sibling is placed out-of-state, the distance between the
sibling's placements is more than 50 miles and one child is placed with a
relative, or one of the siblings is above the age of 16 and refuses such
visits (The above visit exceptions must be recorded in MiSACWIS). The
plan for sibling visits and all reasonable efforts to assure that visits take
place must be documented within the sibling visitation section of the case
service plan.
Two out of eight foster care files did not have sibling visits documented as
occurring monthly. No exceptions were in the file.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - Page 5 - CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN
OUT-OF-HOME PLACEMENT: The caseworker must have at least two face-
to-face contacts per month with the child for the first two months following
an initial placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face contact
with the child must take place within five business days from the date the
case is assigned to the caseworker or within five business days of the date
of the placement move.
Two out of eight foster care files did not have two contacts per month for the first
two months.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - Page 5 - CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN
OUT-OF-HOME PLACEMENT: At least one contact each month must take
place at the child’s placement location.
14

One out of eight foster care files did not have a visit in the foster home
documented. There was no contact for February 2018.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - Page 4 - Private Meeting: Each Contact must
include a private meeting between the child and the caseworker.
Two out of eight foster care files did not document that a private interview was
conducted with the foster child.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H – Page 7 -– Unannounced Home Visit - The
caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home every quarter.
The unan¬nounced visit must be documented in MiSACWIS.
Two out of eight foster care files did not have an unannounced visit documented.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H - Page 10 – CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH
PARENT(S)/ GUARDIAN(S): during the first month of out of home
placement, the caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
with each parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in the parent’s
residence. During subsequent months, the caseworker must have face-to-
face contact with each parent/guardian at least once each calendar month,
with at least one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence
One out of eight foster care files did not have parent contact in their home
quarterly.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - page 7-15 Documentation of Contacts: All
caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this includes
attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all pertinent information
obtained must be summarized and included in the appropriate section of
the case service plan.
One out of eight foster care files did not summarize NEW information in the
monthly contacts with the caregivers. The contact was cut and paste from the
previous months.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H p 15 TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER
CONTACTS All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS within
five business days of the contact.
Three out of eight foster care files did not have timely face to face contacts
documented in the MiSACWIS.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
15

DHHS Policy 722-06B - page 2-6 - Family Team Meetings. The following
events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
• Case service plan development,
• permanency goal changes,
One out of eight foster care files did not have an initial FTM with the initial service
plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
DHHS Policy FOM 722-09C - Page 1-3 DHHS-69 FOSTER CARE ACTION
SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS: Are all required DHHS-69s present?
Four out of four closed foster care files did not have a DHHS-69 in the file.
REPEAT VIOLATION-INTERIM 2017
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12308 : (3) An agency may consider an application withdrawn after 60 days if
the applicant fails to cooperate with the completion of the licensing process.
The agency has 19 relative placements that are not licensed. They have been
enrolled from as early as 2/15/17. The agency is to start sending out letters to the
applicants if they have not been cooperative with the licensing process. The process
is outlined in the Children’s Foster Home Licensing Technical Assistance manual on
page 18.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation in the following areas.
VI. ANALYST CONCERNS AND RESOLUTIONS
SAFETY ALERT 1: There is a beeping smoking detector in the room where one of the
children sleep. There was also a beeping smoke detector on the first floor.
RESOLUTION: The assigned foster care worker visited the home on 10/9/18. The FCW
checked all the batteries. They all were in working order.
SAFETY ALERT 2: None
SAFETY ALERT 3: DHS provided a crib to the relative caregiver that was not CPSC
compliant.
The crib in which the foster child sleeps does not meet CPSC requirements because it
is a portable crib with wheels. It can be folded in scissor like fashion and rolled to a
16

desired location. Although the home is not licensed, the caregiver reported that the crib
was given to her by DHS Oakland County when the child was placed in her home on
June 25, 2018.
After reading case contacts and removal information in MISACWIS, the Analyst
prepared a Safety and Concern Alert to the Area Manager for disposition. The child
was removed on March 29, 2018 for prominent injuries to his body that went from his
face to his legs. There was bleeding in his brain, hemorrhaging to his eyes, and a
laceration to his liver. Social work contacts mention that child wore a helmet, which
Analyst assumed was part of the medical treatment for his injuries.
The non-compliant crib increased the Safe Sleep risk because the child was in the
process of recovery from significant physical injuries that brought him into care.
RESOLUTION: The crib is certified. The crib is JPMA certified which exceeds all safety
standards set by CSPC and ASTM. Picture was provided.
SAFETY ALERT 4: None
SAFETY ALERT 5: None
SAFETY ALERT 6: There were 2 critical safety issues observed in the home:
Critical: CPA must have fixed and provide evidence of resolution to DCWL field
consultant within 5 day of receipt of DCWL Safety Alert.
--Furniture/dressers blocking egress windows
The headboard of the queen sized bed in the girls' bedroom is blocking access to the
egress window.
--Using the basement as recreational space without an egress window that all family
members can climb out of.
The relative stated that the children occasionally play in the basement and that one of
the children still uses the full-sized bathroom in the basement to take showers and get
dressed for the day, as his clothing is still stored in the basement.
This is a relative home; the Analyst discussed basement safety with the caregiver
during the visit. The home is being licensed by Wolverine. The caregiver stated that she
was unaware of the licensing requirement that basements cannot be used for anything
but storage if there is no egress window. She said the children occasionally play in the
basement, as it is finished.
The caregiver stated that Wolverine directed her to move one child from the basement
bedroom to a second-floor bedroom because the basement bedroom did not meet
licensing requirements for an egress window and no viable alternatives. The caregiver
17

said that the licensing worker did not advise her about the safety risks in using the
basement as recreation space.
RESOLUTION: The bed was moved away from the egress window. A face to face visit
was conducted on 9/21/18 to verify. Picture is attached. (Wolverine already addressed
the basement issue per analyst). The relative soon to be licensed foster parent signed
a basement usage agreement.
VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
During the Interim-2017, there were substantial deficits with the writing of
reports. In the licensing department there were violations of R 400.12324 due
to copying and pasting of previous reports. In the foster care department,
Initial Service Plans (ISP) were not completely filled out. Updated Service
Plans (USP) were cut and paste from ISP’s. They lacked summaries of
pertinent information to the case, assessment of progress, and changes
throughout the case. Violations of R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 were present.
There was a pattern of initial documentation not being completed. Initial
placements and subsequent placements did not receive information outlined
in R 400.12404, R 400.12405, and R 400.12417. DHHS-3307’s were not complete
or signed by the caregiver. Relative placements did not have the DHHS-588
completed on time or the 3130A completed on time. Monthly supervision was
not occurring in half thee files. Sibling split PERS were not consistently being
done. Quality case contacts were not completed with the foster children. All
foster care files contained violations in this area. Half of the case files did not
have timely case contact entries. Because of the violations, children safety
was in question.
For 2018 Renewal, the agency has made great strides in many areas. Report writing
has improved. In the licensing department there were no violations pertaining to
Reevaluation reports. Reports were updated. Special investigations were written
well, although one report was missing a CAP. Borrowed beds did not have
documentation of prior approval from the foster parent. Foster parents did not
receive orientation and the PATP from the agency prior to placement. Although this
is an issue, the agency feels confident this can be fixed quickly. In the foster care
18

department. There were no violations under R 400.12419 (ISP writing). ISP’s had all
of the information requested in the reports. R 400.12420 was in violation as a repeat
violation this year, but not as substantial as Interim 2017. In the interim 2017, all of
the files did not have a summary of pertinent information and all of them did not have
an assessment of progress. In this renewal one of the files did not have a summary
of pertinent information and two files did not have an assessment of progress. Initial
documentation, specifically DHHS 3307’s are being completed, with the exception of
one being signed after the placement date by the care giver. There were no
violations pertaining to DHHS 588’s or 3130A’s. Quality case contacts, with the
exception of one file, were completed thoroughly. Supervision was completed
monthly for all case files. It is clear the agency has spent a great deal of time
reviewing reports and case notes. Supervisors noted in interviews they are returning
reports more often and taking longer to review the reports to make sure information
is completed. Intake documentation has been an area monitored and case reviews
have occurred. All workers interviewed relayed the agency has worked together as a
team and they feel supported by their supervisors and administration.
In the upcoming year, the agency will need to continue to work on report writing.
PATP’s were not consistently updated to reflect changes within the case. Medical
passports were not consistently completed with signatures from the caregivers.
Parenting time observation will need to be looked at as well. All closed files did not
have the DHHS-69s available. PERS need to be updated quarterly. Another area
for the licensing department to improve upon is the licensing or denying of enrolled
relatives. The agency also has relatives with placement, that have not been enrolled
to be licensed or waived. Overall the agency has made gains. Looking towards the
next year, the agency will need to maintain those gains as well as improve in the
areas found in violation this renewal.
19

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
11/21/18
